clusters.title: Israeli airstrike kills Houthi prime minister in Yemen, rebels say
clusters.neutral_headline: Israeli Airstrike Kills Houthi Prime Minister in Yemen

items.title: Israeli airstrike kills Houthi prime minister in Yemen, rebels say
items.standfirst: Ahmed al-Rahawi killed alongside several ministers gathered for prerecorded speech by rebel group’s leaderAn Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the Houthi rebel-controlled government in Yemen’s capital, Sana’a, the Houthis have said.Ahmed al-Rahawi was killed in a strike in Sana’a on Thursday along with a number of ministers, the rebels said in a statement on Saturday. Other ministers and officials were wounded, the statement added without providing further details. Continue reading...
items.content: Ahmed al-Rahawi killed alongside several ministers gathered for prerecorded speech by rebel group’s leaderAn Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the Houthi rebel-controlled government in Yemen’s capital, Sana’a, the Houthis have said.Ahmed al-Rahawi was killed in a strike in Sana’a on Thursday along with a number of ministers, the rebels said in a statement on Saturday. Other ministers and officials were wounded, the statement added without providing further details. Continue reading...

items.title: Houthis Confirm Prime Minister & Top Officials Killed In Massive Israeli Strike
items.standfirst: Houthis Confirm Prime Minister & Top Officials Killed In Massive Israeli Strike Yemen's Houthi government has belatedly confirmed that an Israeli attack launched days ago killed its prime minister, Ahmed al-Rahawi, who was the most senior Houthi official to have been slain in the ongoing…
items.content: Houthis Confirm Prime Minister & Top Officials Killed In Massive Israeli Strike Yemen's Houthi government has belatedly confirmed that an Israeli attack launched days ago killed its prime minister, Ahmed al-Rahawi, who was the most senior Houthi official to have been slain in the ongoing…

items.title: After Israeli air strikes kill Houthi prime minister, Israel readies for counter-attack
items.standfirst: Israel is preparing for Houthi retaliation after an Israeli air strike on Thursday killed the Houthi prime minister and other top officials of the Iran-backed rebels in Yemen. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.
items.content: Israel is preparing for Houthi retaliation after an Israeli air strike on Thursday killed the Houthi prime minister and other top officials of the Iran-backed rebels in Yemen. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.

items.title: Houthis confirm their prime minister killed in Israeli strike
items.standfirst: Ahmed Ghaleb Nasser al-Rahawi and several other Houthi officials were killed in the attack, the Iran-backed movement says.
items.content: Ahmed Ghaleb Nasser al-Rahawi and several other Houthi officials were killed in the attack, the Iran-backed movement says.

items.title: Houthi prime minister killed in Israeli air strike on Yemen
items.standfirst: Iran-backed militants confirm death of Ahmed Ghaleb al-Rahawi in bombing of Sana’a on Thursday
items.content: Iran-backed militants confirm death of Ahmed Ghaleb al-Rahawi in bombing of Sana’a on Thursday

items.title: Houthi rebel prime minister killed in Israeli airstrike, militant group says
items.standfirst: Israel has killed the Houthi rebel prime minister Ahmed al Rahawi, the Iranian-backed militant group has said.
items.content: Israel has killed the Houthi rebel prime minister Ahmed al Rahawi, the Iranian-backed militant group has said.

items.title: Yemen's Houthis confirm death of prime minister and other officials in Israeli strike
items.standfirst: The Iran-backed Houthis on Saturday confirmed that an Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the rebel-controlled government and several other ministers in the Yemeni capital, Sanaa, on Thursday.
items.content: The Iran-backed Houthis on Saturday confirmed that an Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the rebel-controlled government and several other ministers in the Yemeni capital, Sanaa, on Thursday.

items.title: Yemen's Houthis confirm death of their leader and several ministers in Israeli strike
Houthi rebels say Israeli airstrike killed their prime minister in Yemen's capital
items.standfirst: The Iranian-backed Houthis said an Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the rebel-controlled government in the Yemeni capital, Sanaa.
items.content: The Iranian-backed Houthis said an Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the rebel-controlled government in the Yemeni capital, Sanaa.(Image credit: Osamah Abdulrahman)

items.title: Yemen’s Houthis confirm prime minister killed in Israeli strike on Sanaa
items.standfirst: Houthis condemn killing of Ahmed al-Rahawi, other government ministers in Israeli attack on Yemen's capital this week.
items.content: Houthis condemn killing of Ahmed al-Rahawi, other government ministers in Israeli attack on Yemen's capital this week.

ai_summary: An Israeli airstrike in Sana'a killed the Houthi prime minister, Ahmed al-Rahawi, and other officials.
The Houthis confirmed the death of their prime minister and top officials in the attack.
Israel is preparing for potential Houthi retaliation following the air strike.
The attack occurred on Thursday, targeting the Iran-backed rebels in Yemen.
Several ministers and officials were also wounded in the Israeli air strike.

clusters.title: Leading Ukrainian politician assassinated in western Ukraine
clusters.neutral_headline: Ukrainian Politician Andriy Parubiy Assassinated in Lviv

items.title: Leading Ukrainian politician assassinated in western Ukraine
items.standfirst: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the "horrific murder" of the leading Ukrainian politician Andriy Parubiy and said all necessary means would be used in the investigation into the killing. FRANCE 24's Emmanuelle Chaze reports frpm Kyiv.
items.content: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the "horrific murder" of the leading Ukrainian politician Andriy Parubiy and said all necessary means would be used in the investigation into the killing. FRANCE 24's Emmanuelle Chaze reports frpm Kyiv.

items.title: Investigation launched into ‘horrific murder’ of Ukrainian politician in Lviv
items.standfirst: Former parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy shot dead as EU ministers meet to discuss measures to force Moscow to the negotiating tableA Ukrainian former parliamentary speaker was shot dead in Lviv on Saturday, authorities said, as European foreign ministers met to discuss increasing pressure on Moscow to end its war against Ukraine.Andriy Parubiy, a member of parliament who served as parliamentary speaker from 2016 to 2019 and a key figure in Ukraine’s 2013 pro-European Maidan revolution, was shot dead, prosecutors said. A murder investigation has been launched and the president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, condemned the killing as a “horrific murder”. Continue reading...
items.content: Former parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy shot dead as EU ministers meet to discuss measures to force Moscow to the negotiating tableA Ukrainian former parliamentary speaker was shot dead in Lviv on Saturday, authorities said, as European foreign ministers met to discuss increasing pressure on Moscow to end its war against Ukraine.Andriy Parubiy, a member of parliament who served as parliamentary speaker from 2016 to 2019 and a key figure in Ukraine’s 2013 pro-European Maidan revolution, was shot dead, prosecutors said. A murder investigation has been launched and the president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, condemned the killing as a “horrific murder”. Continue reading...

items.title: Prominent Ukrainian politician Andriy Parubiy shot dead in Lviv
items.standfirst: President Zelensky said the killing of Parubiy was a "terrible murder" - with a manhunt under way.
items.content: President Zelensky said the killing of Parubiy was a "terrible murder" - with a manhunt under way.

items.title: Prominent Ukrainian nationalist politician shot dead in Lviv
items.standfirst: Assassination of former parliament speaker Andriy Parubiy is the most significant in a series of high-profile killings
items.content: Assassination of former parliament speaker Andriy Parubiy is the most significant in a series of high-profile killings

items.title: Former Ukrainian parliament speaker shot dead in Lviv
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy condemns killing of prominent politician Andriy Parubiy as 'horrendous murder'.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy condemns killing of prominent politician Andriy Parubiy as 'horrendous murder'.

items.title: Ukrainian lawmaker shot dead in Lviv as Zelenskyy says hunt for killer is under way – as it happened
items.standfirst: This live blog is now closedAndriy Parubiy, a Ukrainian politician who previously served as the parliament speaker, has been shot dead in western city of Lviv, say officials.Confirming the news, Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy wrote on X:Ukraine’s minister of internal affairs Ihor Klymenko and prosecutor general Ruslan Kravchenko have just reported the first known circumstances of the horrendous murder in Lviv. Andriy Parubiy was killed.My condolences to his family and loved ones. All necessary forces and means are engaged in the investigation and search for the killer. Continue reading...
items.content: This live blog is now closedAndriy Parubiy, a Ukrainian politician who previously served as the parliament speaker, has been shot dead in western city of Lviv, say officials.Confirming the news, Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy wrote on X:Ukraine’s minister of internal affairs Ihor Klymenko and prosecutor general Ruslan Kravchenko have just reported the first known circumstances of the horrendous murder in Lviv. Andriy Parubiy was killed.My condolences to his family and loved ones. All necessary forces and means are engaged in the investigation and search for the killer. Continue reading...

items.title: Pro-Western Ukrainian politician shot dead
items.standfirst: A former speaker of the Ukrainian parliament has been shot dead in Lviv.
items.content: A former speaker of the Ukrainian parliament has been shot dead in Lviv.

items.title: Leading Ukrainian 'statesman' and 'patriot' assassinated in western Ukraine
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the “horrific murder” of Andriy Parubiy, 54, a leading figure in Ukraine’s pro-European protest movements who was shot and killed in Lviv on Saturday. A former speaker of parliament, Parubiy also previously served as secretary of the National Security and Defence Council.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the “horrific murder” of Andriy Parubiy, 54, a leading figure in Ukraine’s pro-European protest movements who was shot and killed in Lviv on Saturday. A former speaker of parliament, Parubiy also previously served as secretary of the National Security and Defence Council.

ai_summary: Former Ukrainian parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy was shot dead in Lviv.
President Zelenskyy condemned the killing as a "horrific murder".
A murder investigation has been launched into the assassination.
The killing is considered the most significant in a series of high-profile killings.
European foreign ministers met to discuss increasing pressure on Moscow.

clusters.title: Johnson signs executive order against possible deployment of federal agents to Chicago
clusters.neutral_headline: Chicago Mayor Signs Order to Resist Trump Immigration Crackdown

items.title: Johnson signs executive order against possible deployment of federal agents to Chicago
items.standfirst: The signing of the "Protecting Chicago Initiative" comes amid growing concerns of federal agents arriving in the city as soon as Friday.
items.content: The signing of the "Protecting Chicago Initiative" comes amid growing concerns of federal agents arriving in the city as soon as Friday.

items.title: Chicago mayor pushes back on Trump's immigration crackdown
items.standfirst: Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson detailed his plan Saturday to resist President Trump's threatened immigration crackdown in his city. CBS News has learned the Trump administration plans to intensify immigration enforcement in the city as early as next week. Willie James Inman has more.
items.content: Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson detailed his plan Saturday to resist President Trump's threatened immigration crackdown in his city. CBS News has learned the Trump administration plans to intensify immigration enforcement in the city as early as next week. Willie James Inman has more.

items.title: Chicago mayor signs executive order directing city to resist Trump’s immigration raids
items.standfirst: Brandon Johnson’s order directs city police not to collaborate with federal agents in immigration enforcementThe mayor of Chicago has signed an executive order outlining how the city will attempt to resist Donald Trump’s immigration crackdown.Brandon Johnson pushed back on Saturday against what he called the “out-of-control” Trump administration’s plan to deploy large numbers of federal officers into the country’s third-largest city, which could take place within days. Continue reading...
items.content: Brandon Johnson’s order directs city police not to collaborate with federal agents in immigration enforcementThe mayor of Chicago has signed an executive order outlining how the city will attempt to resist Donald Trump’s immigration crackdown.Brandon Johnson pushed back on Saturday against what he called the “out-of-control” Trump administration’s plan to deploy large numbers of federal officers into the country’s third-largest city, which could take place within days. Continue reading...

items.title: Chicago mayor signs order to resist potential Trump crackdown
items.standfirst: The order is the latest chapter in an escalating feud between the White House and Illinois state officials over violent crime and immigration.
items.content: The order is the latest chapter in an escalating feud between the White House and Illinois state officials over violent crime and immigration.

items.title: Chicago mayor signs order to resist possible Trump troop deployment
items.standfirst: Mayor Brandon Johnson says order aims to protect residents from 'threats and actions of out-of-control administration'.
items.content: Mayor Brandon Johnson says order aims to protect residents from 'threats and actions of out-of-control administration'.

items.title: Chicago Mayor Signs Order to Resist Trump Immigration Crackdown
items.standfirst: Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson signed an order that would block possible immigration raids from the Trump administration.
items.content: Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson signed an order that would block possible immigration raids from the Trump administration.

ai_summary: Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson signed an executive order to resist potential immigration raids.
The order directs city police not to collaborate with federal immigration agents.
The mayor is pushing back against the Trump administration's planned crackdown.
The Trump administration plans to intensify immigration enforcement in Chicago.
The order aims to protect residents from the "out-of-control administration".

clusters.title: At least three dead after Indonesian parliament building set ablaze - as violent protests rage on
clusters.neutral_headline: Protests Erupt in Indonesia After Parliament Building Fire

items.title: At least three dead after Indonesian parliament building set ablaze - as violent protests rage on
items.standfirst: At least three people have died after protesters set fire to a regional parliament building in Indonesia during a fifth day of unrest.
items.content: At least three people have died after protesters set fire to a regional parliament building in Indonesia during a fifth day of unrest.

items.title: Fire kills three people in Indonesia after protesters torch council buildings
items.standfirst: Cities in Indonesia rocked by protests after motorcycle taxi driver run over by police tactical vehicleProtesters have torched parliamentary buildings in three further Indonesian provinces, a day after at least three people were killed by a fire started by demonstrators at a council building in the city of Makassar.Protests erupted across Indonesia after footage spread showing a motorcycle taxi driver being run over and killed by a police vehicle on Thursday night during earlier demonstrations over low wages for workers and perks for lawmakers. Continue reading...
items.content: Cities in Indonesia rocked by protests after motorcycle taxi driver run over by police tactical vehicleProtesters have torched parliamentary buildings in three further Indonesian provinces, a day after at least three people were killed by a fire started by demonstrators at a council building in the city of Makassar.Protests erupted across Indonesia after footage spread showing a motorcycle taxi driver being run over and killed by a police vehicle on Thursday night during earlier demonstrations over low wages for workers and perks for lawmakers. Continue reading...

items.title: Fire set by protesters in Indonesia kills three amid a wave of urban unrest
items.standfirst: Three people were killed in Makassar on the eastern Indonesian island of Sulawesi after a city council building was set ablaze by protesters amid a wave of unrest that rocked major Indonesian cities – the most violent protests of Prabowo Subianto’s presidency. Prabowo cancelled a planned trip to China next week in order to monitor the situation in Indonesia.
items.content: Three people were killed in Makassar on the eastern Indonesian island of Sulawesi after a city council building was set ablaze by protesters amid a wave of unrest that rocked major Indonesian cities – the most violent protests of Prabowo Subianto’s presidency. Prabowo cancelled a planned trip to China next week in order to monitor the situation in Indonesia.

items.title: 3 dead after mob sets fire to Indonesian regional parliament building
items.standfirst: An angry mob set fire to a local parliament building in an Indonesian provincial capital, leaving at least three people dead and five others hospitalized, officials said.
items.content: An angry mob set fire to a local parliament building in an Indonesian provincial capital, leaving at least three people dead and five others hospitalized, officials said.(Image credit: Masyudi Firmansyah)

items.title: Protests erupt in Indonesia over death of man hit by police vehicle
items.standfirst: Government faces calls for police reform amid violent clashes across Jakarta and demonstrations in other citiesHundreds of Indonesians have protested at sites across Jakarta over the death of a man hit by a police vehicle, in the first big test for Prabowo Subianto’s nearly year-old government.The man, a motorcycle ride-sharing driver, was hit at the site of violent clashes near parliament on Thursday as police sought to disperse demonstrators protesting about a number of issues including lawmakers’ pay and education funding. Continue reading...
items.content: Government faces calls for police reform amid violent clashes across Jakarta and demonstrations in other citiesHundreds of Indonesians have protested at sites across Jakarta over the death of a man hit by a police vehicle, in the first big test for Prabowo Subianto’s nearly year-old government.The man, a motorcycle ride-sharing driver, was hit at the site of violent clashes near parliament on Thursday as police sought to disperse demonstrators protesting about a number of issues including lawmakers’ pay and education funding. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Protesters set fire to a regional parliament building in Indonesia, killing three.
Protests erupted after a motorcycle taxi driver was killed by a police vehicle.
The government faces calls for police reform amid violent clashes.
The unrest is the most violent of Prabowo Subianto’s presidency.
Prabowo cancelled a planned trip to China to monitor the situation.

clusters.title: US denies visas to Palestinian Authority leaders heading to UN General Assembly
clusters.neutral_headline: US blocks Palestinian leaders from attending UN meeting

items.title: US denies visas to Palestinian Authority leaders heading to UN General Assembly
items.standfirst: The State Department said Friday that it would deny visas to members of the Palestinian Authority for next month’s UN General Assembly, including Palestinian Authority president Mahmoud Abbas. Under an agreement as the host of UN headquarters in New York, the US is not supposed to refuse visas for officials heading to the world body. Here’s General Secretary at the Palestinian National initiative, Mustafa Barghouti speech.
items.content: The State Department said Friday that it would deny visas to members of the Palestinian Authority for next month’s UN General Assembly, including Palestinian Authority president Mahmoud Abbas. Under an agreement as the host of UN headquarters in New York, the US is not supposed to refuse visas for officials heading to the world body. Here’s General Secretary at the Palestinian National initiative, Mustafa Barghouti speech.

items.title: U.S. blocks Palestinian leaders from attending U.N. meeting in New York
items.standfirst: Members of Mahmoud Abbas' Palestinian government will be unable to travel to the United Nations General Assembly after Marco Rubio revoked their visas.
items.content: Members of Mahmoud Abbas' Palestinian government will be unable to travel to the United Nations General Assembly after Marco Rubio revoked their visas.

items.title: US denies visas to Palestinian Authority leaders heading to UN General Assembly
items.standfirst: The State Department said Friday that it would deny visas to members of the Palestinian Authority for next month’s UN General Assembly, prompting France to urge Washington to allow full Palestinian participation. Under an agreement as the host of UN headquarters in New York, the US is not supposed to refuse visas for officials heading to the world body. Washington Bureau Chief at The Guardian, David Smith, tells us more.
items.content: The State Department said Friday that it would deny visas to members of the Palestinian Authority for next month’s UN General Assembly, prompting France to urge Washington to allow full Palestinian participation. Under an agreement as the host of UN headquarters in New York, the US is not supposed to refuse visas for officials heading to the world body. Washington Bureau Chief at The Guardian, David Smith, tells us more.

items.title: US blocks Palestinian leader from attending UN meeting in New York
items.standfirst: The decision comes as France leads international efforts to recognise a Palestinian state at the UN meeting next month.
items.content: The decision comes as France leads international efforts to recognise a Palestinian state at the UN meeting next month.

items.title: US blocks Palestinian president and 80 other officials from United Nations meeting
items.standfirst: Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas and 80 other officials have been blocked from attending September's annual meeting of the United Nations General Assembly in New York.
items.content: Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas and 80 other officials have been blocked from attending September's annual meeting of the United Nations General Assembly in New York.

ai_summary: The US State Department denied visas to Palestinian Authority leaders.
The denial includes Palestinian Authority president Mahmoud Abbas.
The US is not supposed to refuse visas for officials heading to the UN.
France is urging the US to allow full Palestinian participation.
The decision impacts the upcoming UN General Assembly meeting.

items.title: Xi meets foreign leaders ahead of SCO summit
items.standfirst: Chinese President Xi Jinping met with foreign leaders ahead of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit that will be held from August 31 to September 1 in the port city of Tianjin. Xi welcom...

items.title: Xi meets Modi as China and India reengage under Trump tariffs
items.standfirst: SHANGHAI -- Chinese President Xi Jinping met Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday, state media reported, as leaders from across the region convened in the Chinese city of Tianjin for the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit. New concerns over US policy shift neighbors' focus…
items.content: SHANGHAI -- Chinese President Xi Jinping met Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday, state media reported, as leaders from across the region convened in the Chinese city of Tianjin for the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit. New concerns over US policy shift neighbors' focus…

items.title: Xi hosts Putin, Modi at SCO summit in show of Global South unity
items.standfirst: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order".
items.content: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order".

items.title: China supports UN’s global role, Xi tells Guterres before SCO summit
items.standfirst: The UN chief says he values China's support, where he is attending the 2025 Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit.
items.content: The UN chief says he values China's support, where he is attending the 2025 Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit.

ai_summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping met with foreign leaders in Tianjin.
The Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit will be held in Tianjin.
The summit aims to boost Beijing’s influence and promote a multipolar world.
Xi met with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi at the summit.
The UN chief attended the summit and values China's support.

items.title: Spirit Airlines stock is in a crater amid second bankruptcy
items.standfirst: After months of reassurances that it was finally on a better financial path, low-cost carrier Spirit Airlines (SAVE) has filed for renewed bankruptcy protection just nine months after emerging from Chapter 11 reorganization. While the Florida-based airline is still running flights and allowing…
items.content: After months of reassurances that it was finally on a better financial path, low-cost carrier Spirit Airlines (SAVE) has filed for renewed bankruptcy protection just nine months after emerging from Chapter 11 reorganization. items.title: Spirit Airlines files for bankruptcy again but vows to keep flying
items.standfirst: MIAMI — Budget carrier Spirit Airlines said Friday that it has filed for fresh bankruptcy protection months after emerging from a Chapter 11 reorganization. The ultra low-cost airline said it plans to keep flying as usual during the restructuring process, meaning passengers can still book trips…
items.content: MIAMI — Budget carrier Spirit Airlines said Friday that it has filed for fresh bankruptcy protection months after emerging from a Chapter 11 reorganization. The ultra low-cost airline said it plans to keep flying as usual during the restructuring process, meaning passengers can still book trips…

items.title: Spirit Airlines files for bankruptcy for 2nd time in less than a year
items.standfirst: The budget carrier filed for fresh bankruptcy protection months after emerging from a Chapter 11 reorganization. The airline said it plans to keep flying as usual during the restructuring process.
items.content: The budget carrier filed for fresh bankruptcy protection months after emerging from a Chapter 11 reorganization. The airline said it plans to keep flying as usual during the restructuring process.(Image credit: Charles Krupa)

items.title: Spirit Airlines files for bankruptcy protection for second time in a year
items.standfirst: Low-cost carrier experiences dwindling cash and mounting losses as recovery further hit by Trump tariffs US no-frills pioneer Spirit Airlines filed for fresh chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Friday, as dwindling cash and mounting losses derailed its turnaround efforts since emerging from a previous Chapter 11 reorganization in March.The carrier, recognizable by its bright yellow jets, has struggled to steady operations since emerging from its first bankruptcy in March. Flights, ticket sales, reservations and operations will continue, the airline said on Friday. Continue reading...
items.content: Low-cost carrier experiences dwindling cash and mounting losses as recovery further hit by Trump tariffs US no-frills pioneer Spirit Airlines filed for fresh chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Friday, as dwindling cash and mounting losses derailed its turnaround efforts since emerging from a previous Chapter 11 reorganization in March.The carrier, recognizable by its bright yellow jets, has struggled to steady operations since emerging from its first bankruptcy in March. Flights, ticket sales, reservations and operations will continue, the airline said on Friday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Spirit Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection for the second time in a year.
The airline plans to keep flying as usual during the restructuring.
The low-cost carrier is experiencing dwindling cash and mounting losses.
Spirit emerged from a previous Chapter 11 reorganization in March.
The airline has struggled to steady operations since the first bankruptcy.

items.title: More than 500 workers at Voice of America and other broadcasters to be laid off
items.standfirst: Acting CEO of parent agency makes announcement one day after judge blocks her from firing VOA director The agency that oversees Voice of America and other government-funded international broadcasters is eliminating jobs for more than 500 employees, a Trump administration official said. The move…
items.content: Acting CEO of parent agency makes announcement one day after judge blocks her from firing VOA director The agency that oversees Voice of America and other government-funded international broadcasters is eliminating jobs for more than 500 employees, a Trump administration official said. The move…

items.title: More than 500 workers at Voice of America and other broadcasters to be laid off
items.standfirst: Acting CEO of parent agency makes announcement one day after judge blocks her from firing VOA directorThe agency that oversees Voice of America and other government-funded international broadcasters is eliminating jobs for more than 500 employees, a Trump administration official said. The move could ratchet up a months-long legal challenge over the news outlets’ fate.Kari Lake, acting CEO of the US Agency for Global Media, announced the latest round of job cuts late Friday, one day after a federal judge blocked her from removing Michael Abramowitz as VOA director. Continue reading...
items.content: Acting CEO of parent agency makes announcement one day after judge blocks her from firing VOA directorThe agency that oversees Voice of America and other government-funded international broadcasters is eliminating jobs for more than 500 employees, a Trump administration official said. The move could ratchet up a months-long legal challenge over the news outlets’ fate.Kari Lake, acting CEO of the US Agency for Global Media, announced the latest round of job cuts late Friday, one day after a federal judge blocked her from removing Michael Abramowitz as VOA director. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump administration moves to fire most Voice of America journalists
items.standfirst: Termination notices have been issued to more than 500 employees of VOA and its parent agency.
items.content: Termination notices have been issued to more than 500 employees of VOA and its parent agency.

ai_summary: The agency overseeing Voice of America is eliminating over 500 jobs.
The job cuts were announced by the acting CEO of the US Agency for Global Media.
A federal judge blocked the acting CEO from firing the VOA director.
Termination notices have been issued to VOA and its parent agency employees.
The move could escalate a legal challenge over the news outlets' fate.

items.title: Mass held at site of Minneapolis church shooting
items.standfirst: For the first time since this week's deadly mass shooting at a Minneapolis church, which killed two young students and wounded more than a dozen people, a devastated community gathered Saturday at the site to attend Mass. Ashley Grams has more.
items.content: For the first time since this week's deadly mass shooting at a Minneapolis church, which killed two young students and wounded more than a dozen people, a devastated community gathered Saturday at the site to attend Mass. Ashley Grams has more.

items.title: UK chasing £90m in taxes from temp staffing firm rescued from insolvency
items.standfirst: The £18m deal to acquire Challenge Recruitment Group assets from administration repaid private funders in full The UK exchequer is chasing about £90m in unpaid taxes after a temporary staffing business was rescued from insolvency proceedings in an £18m deal that reimbursed private funders in…
items.content: The £18m deal to acquire Challenge Recruitment Group assets from administration repaid private funders in full The UK exchequer is chasing about £90m in unpaid taxes after a temporary staffing business was rescued from insolvency proceedings in an £18m deal that reimbursed private funders in…

items.title: UK chasing £90m in taxes from temp staffing firm rescued from insolvency
items.standfirst: The £18m deal to acquire Challenge Recruitment Group assets from administration repaid private funders in fullThe UK exchequer is chasing about £90m in unpaid taxes after a temporary staffing business was rescued from insolvency proceedings in an £18m deal that reimbursed private funders in full.The main assets of Challenge Recruitment Group, which counted Tesco, Sainsbury’s and Co-op among its top customers, were acquired from administration in July by the US website swipejobs, in what appears to be the second time the British staffing business has emerged from insolvency while owing tens of millions of pounds to the exchequer. Continue reading...
items.content: The £18m deal to acquire Challenge Recruitment Group assets from administration repaid private funders in fullThe UK exchequer is chasing about £90m in unpaid taxes after a temporary staffing business was rescued from insolvency proceedings in an £18m deal that reimbursed private funders in full.The main assets of Challenge Recruitment Group, which counted Tesco, Sainsbury’s and Co-op among its top customers, were acquired from administration in July by the US website swipejobs, in what appears to be the second time the British staffing business has emerged from insolvency while owing tens of millions of pounds to the exchequer. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The UK exchequer is chasing about £90m in unpaid taxes.
A temporary staffing business was rescued from insolvency.
The rescue involved an £18m deal that reimbursed private funders.
The main assets were acquired by the US website swipejobs.
The staffing business previously owed tens of millions in taxes.

The brothers' achievement sets a new world record for the fastest Pacific row.

items.content: A US appeals court has ruled that most of Trump’s tariffs are illegal - so what happens now?

items.title: US court rules Trump's tariffs are illegal - but leaves them in place for now
items.standfirst: Donald Trump's tariffs are unconstitutional, but they can remain in place for now, the US Court of Appeals has said.

clusters.title: US appeals court rules most of Trump's tariffs illegal under federal law
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Tariffs Ruled Illegal by US Appeals Court

items.title: US appeals court rules most of Trump's tariffs illegal under federal law
items.standfirst: A US appeals court found President Donald Trump exceeded his powers by invoking emergency authority to levy sweeping global tariffs, deeming most of them illegal but letting them stand until mid-October. Trump announced he would challenge the ruling at the Supreme Court. Shirli Sitbon tells us more.
items.content: A US appeals court found President Donald Trump exceeded his powers by invoking emergency authority to levy sweeping global tariffs, deeming most of them illegal but letting them stand until mid-October. Trump announced he would challenge the ruling at the Supreme Court. Shirli Sitbon tells us more.

items.title: Most of Trump’s tariffs are illegal, federal court rules
items.standfirst: US president found to have overstepped authority with tariff policies and accuses court of political biasDonald Trump overstepped his presidential powers with most of his globe-rattling tariff policies, a federal appeals court in Washington DC ruled on Friday.US law “bestows significant authority on the president to undertake a number of actions in response to a declared national emergency, but none of these actions explicitly include the power to impose tariffs, duties, or the like, or the power to tax”, the court said in the 7-4 ruling. Continue reading...
items.content: US president found to have overstepped authority with tariff policies and accuses court of political biasDonald Trump overstepped his presidential powers with most of his globe-rattling tariff policies, a federal appeals court in Washington DC ruled on Friday.US law “bestows significant authority on the president to undertake a number of actions in response to a declared national emergency, but none of these actions explicitly include the power to impose tariffs, duties, or the like, or the power to tax”, the court said in the 7-4 ruling. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A US appeals court ruled that most of Trump's tariffs were illegal.
The court found Trump overstepped his authority with his tariff policies.
The court's ruling deemed most tariffs illegal but allowed them to remain.
The court stated Trump lacked the power to impose tariffs under the law.
Trump announced he would challenge the ruling at the Supreme Court.

clusters.title: Israel declares Gaza City a "combat zone": Death toll surpasses 63,000
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Declares Gaza City a "Combat Zone

items.title: Israel declares Gaza City a "combat zone": Death toll surpasses 63,000
items.standfirst: The Israeli military on Friday declared Gaza City a “dangerous combat zone” before a new offensive in the Palestinian enclave's largest city. Israel is moving forward with plans to seize Gaza City despite growing international pressure to end the nearly two-year conflict. France24 correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky reports the latest from Jerusalem.
items.content: The Israeli military on Friday declared Gaza City a “dangerous combat zone” before a new offensive in the Palestinian enclave's largest city. Israel is moving forward with plans to seize Gaza City despite growing international pressure to end the nearly two-year conflict. France24 correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky reports the latest from Jerusalem.

items.title: Israeli military recovers remains of 2 hostages and declares Gaza City a dangerous combat zone
items.standfirst: Israel said Friday that Gaza's largest city was now a dangerous combat zone as it began the “initial stages” of its assault on the famine-gripped area, and that its military had recovered the remains of two hostages from the territory."We are not waiting," the Israel Defense Forces said in a statement.
items.content: Israel said Friday that Gaza's largest city was now a dangerous combat zone as it began the “initial stages” of its assault on the famine-gripped area, and that its military had recovered the remains of two hostages from the territory."We are not waiting," the Israel Defense Forces said in a statement.

ai_summary: The Israeli military declared Gaza City a "dangerous combat zone".
The declaration preceded a new offensive in Gaza City.
Israel is moving forward with plans to seize Gaza City.
The Israeli military recovered the remains of two hostages.
The death toll in the conflict has surpassed 63,000.

clusters.title: Why has Kamala Harris' security detail been withdrawn?
clusters.neutral_headline: Why has Kamala Harris' security detail been withdrawn?

items.title: Why has Kamala Harris' security detail been withdrawn?
items.standfirst: The overstretched Secret Service is required to provide 6 months of protection to former vice-presidents.
items.content: The overstretched Secret Service is required to provide 6 months of protection to former vice-presidents.

items.title: Trump revokes Harris’ security protections after Biden-issued extension
items.standfirst: The former vice president is set to start a book tour soon.
items.content: President Donald Trump discontinued former Vice President Kamala Harris’ Secret Service protection on Thursday, according to a memo reviewed by POLITICO. In a memo titled “Memorandum for the Secretary of Homeland Security,” and dated Aug. 28, Trump directed the Secret Service to revoke Harris’ security protections, effective Sept. 1. “You are hereby authorized to discontinue any security-related procedures previously authorized by Executive Memorandum, beyond those required by law, for the following individual effective September 1, 2025: Former Vice President Kamala D. Harris,” the memo read. The move, first disclosed by CNN, comes as Harris is set to embark on a 15-city tour to promote her new book, “107 Days,” starting next month. The tour will place the former vice president — who has remained largely out of the public eye since leaving office in January — back in the spotlight. “The Vice President is grateful to the United States Secret Service for their professionalism, dedication, and unwavering commitment to safety,” Harris spokesperson Kirsten Allen said in a statement. Former President Joe Biden had initially extended Harris’ Secret Service protection — which had been set to last until only mid-July — for an additional year, according to a person familiar with the move who was granted anonymity to discuss security arrangements. While presidents receive lifelong protection after leaving office, coverage for vice presidents typically lasts only six months after they leave office. A White House spokesperson confirmed protection has been revoked but did not comment further. Trump similarly ended extended security protections for Hunter Biden and his half-sister Ashley Biden earlier this year.

ai_summary: The Secret Service is required to provide six months of protection to former vice presidents.
Trump revoked Harris' security protections after Biden-issued extension.
Harris is set to start a book tour soon.
The Secret Service is responsible for protecting former vice presidents.
The withdrawal of security detail has raised questions.
